intro: Quercus nigra var. quinqueloba, commonly known as the five-lobed water oak, is a deciduous tree native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its distinctive five-lobed leaves that are often hairy on the underside. The tree produces small, reddish-brown acorns that are enclosed in a cupule. It typically grows to a height of 20–30 meters and has a broad, spreading canopy. The bark is thick and scaly, providing a rugged appearance.
